newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong gold rebounds on overseas buying.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong gold rebounds on overseas buying.

text.p: Hong Kong's gold market recovered some of its composure on Wednesday to end a shade up from New York's Tuesday close after afternoon European buying buoyed the market, gold dealers and traders said.
The selling spree on Tuesday had quietened down by Wednesday as earlier producer sales, triggered by fears of a huge price slump, slowed down considerably, they said.
But volumes remained small and gaps between bids and offers were too unrealistic for many deals to be concluded, industry sources said.
"People want to buy between $378.00-378.25 and on the upside people want to offer around $379.00-379.50, so the gold market was quiet," Swiss Bank Corp's chief dealer Anderson Cheung said.
Hong Kong kicked off the morning with gold sales from the Tokyo Commodity Exchange (TOCOM) sparked by a higher dollar/yen, dealers said.
The afternoon saw European buying recover and gold moved steadily up to close at US$379.00/50 an ounce Wednesday against New York's US$378.70/379.20 close on Tuesday.
Local gold ended HK$13 higher at HK$3,495 a tael.
The carry over charge at the Chinese Gold and Silver Exchange Society rose to -5 from its fix at -6 on Tuesday.
Demand for physical gold remained quiet with China's National Day holiday further dampening enthusiasm.
A slight wave of physical buying when prices approached $378 had died down by Wednesday, traders said.
Hong Kong traders saw little chance of shortcovering hitting the market, noting that shorts were comfortable and the market remained technically bearish.
Following the rebound in New York on Tuesday, the market would hold around $378 over the next couple of days, dealers said.
